contentrichtext.text: {{Automatic taxobox | name = Shrew opossums | image = Shrew opossum - Caenolestidae.png | image_width = 240px | fossil_range = {{Fossil range|Late Oligocene|Recent}} | taxon = Caenolestidae | authority = [[Édouard Louis Trouessart|Trouessart]], 1898 | parent_authority = [[Florentino Ameghino|Ameghino]], 1894 | subdivision_ranks = Genera | subdivision = '''Caenolestinae'''<br /> :''[[Caenolestes]]'' :''[[Lestoros]]'' :''[[Pseudhalmarhiphus]]'' (†) :''[[Rhyncholestes]]'' :''[[Stilotherium]]'' (†) '''Pichipilinae''' (†)<br /> :''[[Phonocdromus]]'' (†) :''[[Pichipilus]]'' (†) :''[[Pliolestes]]'' (†) }} The [[order (biology)|order]] '''Paucituberculata''' {{IPAc-en|ˌ|p|ɔː|s|ɨ|ˌ|tj|uː|b|ər|k|jʉ|ˈ|l|ɑː|t|ə}} contains the six surviving species of '''shrew opossum''': small, [[shrew]]-like [[marsupial]]s which are confined to the [[Andes]] mountains of [[South America]].<ref name=msw3>{{MSW3 Paucituberculata | heading = Family Caenolestidae | id = 10500002 | pages = 19–20}}</ref> The order is thought to have diverged from the ancestral marsupial line very early. As recently as 20 million years ago, at least seven genera were in South America. Today, just three genera remain. They live in inaccessible forest and grassland regions of the High Andes. [[Insectivora|Insectivore]]s were entirely absent from South America until the [[Great American Interchange]] three million years ago, and are currently present only in the northwestern part of the continent. Shrew opossums have lost ground to these and other [[Eutheria|placental]] invaders that fill the same [[ecological niche]]s. Nevertheless, the ranges of shrew opossums and insectivores overlap broadly. Shrew opossums (also known as '''rat opossums''' or '''caenolestids''') are about the size of a small rat (9–14 cm long), with thin limbs, a long, pointed snout and a slender, hairy tail. They are largely carnivorous, being active hunters of [[insect]]s, [[earthworm]]s, and small vertebrates. They have small eyes and poor sight, and hunt in the early evening and at night, using their hearing and long, sensitive [[whisker]]s to locate prey. They seem to spend much of their lives in underground burrows and on surface runways. Largely because of their rugged, inaccessible habitat, they are very poorly known and have traditionally been considered rare. Recent studies suggest they may be more common than had been thought. ==Classification== Within the family of the '''Caenolestidae''', six species are known: * Genus ''[[Caenolestes]]'' ** [[Gray-bellied caenolestid]], ''Caenolestes caniventer'' ** [[Andean caenolestid]], ''Caenolestes condorensis'' ** [[Northern caenolestid]], ''Caenolestes convelatus'' ** [[Dusky caenolestid]], ''Caenolestes fuliginosus'' * Genus ''[[Lestoros]]'' ** Peruvian or [[Incan caenolestid]], ''Lestoros inca'' * Genus ''[[Rhyncholestes]]'' ** [[Long-nosed caenolestid]], ''Rhyncholestes raphanurus'' However, Bublitz{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} suggested in 1987 there were actually two ''Lestoros'' and ''Rhyncholestes'' species (those listed here plus ''L. gracilis'' and ''R. continentalis''). This is, however, not accepted by most scientists. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Mammals}} {{Paucituberculata}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shrew Opossum}} [[Category:Shrew opossums| ]] [[Category:Living fossils]]
